The case was bent, scratched, and won't close properly. I happen to love this movie so I thought I would just keep this one and order a replacement. Problem is, the second steelbox was just as damaged. I gave the 3 star rating because there is no damage to the discs. I'm not pleased and I'm not going to try to get a replacement on Amazon. I didn't see it for such a long time, because I just don't like the Dude character.  Or any of the others -- it's just a story about rotten people with some of them doing good sporadically and the rest working an angle.  Most of them we pretty certifiable and not entertaining anti-hero role models, but who am I to grouse -- the thing works.

If you never have seen it yet and are reading this deeply into the reviews -- maybe they should do a film of your life if you were born before 1990.  Jsut sayin', heh.

As a college student with a very busy schedule, life can be very stressful at times. For me, when I get stressed I watch films. This has been my favorite pastimes for many years and, in those years, I have seen many movies. Some of the movies have been entertaining and well made, while others have been complete failures. One film that is among the more memorable is the Coen brothers film The Big Lebowski. This 1998 comedy is certainly one of the best, and most hilarious, films I have ever watched. The hilarious dialogue, enthralling story, and great acting are what make The Big Lebowski one of the most influential films in recent years.
 The dialogue is one of the most effective pieces in this film. It is certainly a film that I, and many people around me, quote frequently. One of the most memorable lines in the movie is the classic, The rug really tied the room together, (The Big Lebowski), which is repeated numerous times throughout the film. This is funny because the rug, that is so frequently mentioned, was urinated on at the very beginning of the movie and, it is the only reason why the Dude pushes on through the madness during the film. Another, and equally memorable, quote in the film is at the very end of the film when the Dude utters, Yeah? Well, the Dude abides, (The Big Lebowski). This laid back comment is so comical because the Dude has gone through so much at this point in the film, yet he is still content with the way things ended up. The memorable dialogue in The Big Lebowski is credited to the movies brilliant writers Joel and Ethan Coen, who also directed the film.
 Another great component of the Coen brothers writing can be seen in the films outrageous story. There are so many twists and turns in this movie which just adds to the hilarity of it all. The film starts with a bang when the Dude returns to his home, after grocery shopping, and is attacked by two men asking, Wheres the money Lebowski? (The Big Lebowski). The comedy in this scene comes from, the Dude getting mistaken for another Jeffrey Lebowski, and being the inciting incident that throws the Dude immediately into his absurd quest for a new rug. Another hilarious part of the film is when John Goodmans character, Walter Sobchak the Vietnam War vet, destroys a Corvette  he mistakenly thought was a young boys, with a crowbar, which resulted in the cars true owner smashing the Dudes car. In any movie, no matter how good the writing is, the actors must be able to deliver it in a way that is believable. In the case of The Big Lebowski, it must also be funny, and that is exactly what the actors were able to accomplish.
 The acting is by far the most important aspect of the entire movie. Everyone who was cast in The Big Lebowski was able to deliver every joke with great timing, yet make their character believable even though the story is so off the wall. Jeff Bridges portrayal of the Dude could not have been better because he was able to make the absurdity going on around him completely believable. A great example of Bridges ability to do this is in the scene where the Dude gets one of his friends ashes thrown in his face while spreading them in the ocean. What makes Jeff Bridges acting so funny in this scene is his stoic face and almost non-existent reaction. John Goodman also did a fantastic job as Walter in this film. As his character, Goodman had to go from being completely calm, to being furious, back to acting completely calm in an instant and thats exactly what he did. The scene that Goodman demonstrates this best is when he pulls a gun on one of his friends for not marking their foul while bowling. To this day, whenever I see Bridges in a film, I immediately think of the Dude.
 While there are many fans of the film, it is, of course, not for everyone. The biggest complaint I have heard from the people that I have recommended the movie to has been that, while there are many surprises in it, the film doesnt really go anywhere, which is exactly what I thought the first time I watched the film. Although I do see their point, I think the reason why somebody would say something like this is because, what the Dude is trying to do is get a new rug, since the two men from the beginning of the film peed on his first one. This, to most people, is not a story worth telling or watching, but the movie is more about the Dudes journey than what he is seeking.
I would recommend The Big Lebowski to anybody looking for a good laugh. The one piece of advice I would give, though, is that if you don't like it the first time give it at least one more chance, if not two chances, all the way through. Because of the films memorable dialogue, ridiculous story, and great acting, I would give The Big Lebowski a whole hearted A+.

Near-perfect writing, quirky characters, and career-best acting performances across the board make the clever plot almost superfluous. An homage love-letter to classic Hollywood tropes, but besting many of its references. Too quirky to be mainstream; far too good to be considered a "cult classic." One of my personal top 5 movies, overall. Tour de force.

Way out west there was this fella... fella I wanna tell ya about. Fella by the name of Jeff Lebowski. At least that was the handle his loving parents gave him, but he never had much use for it himself. Mr. Lebowski, he called himself "The Dude". Now, "Dude" - that's a name no one would self-apply where I come from. But then there was a lot about the Dude that didn't make a whole lot of sense. And a lot about where he lived, likewise. But then again, maybe that's why I found the place so darned interestin'.

They call Los Angeles the "City Of Angels." I didn't find it to be that, exactly. But I'll allow there are some nice folks there. 'Course I can't say I've seen London, and I ain't never been to France. And I ain't never seen no queen in her damned undies, so the feller says. But I'll tell you what - after seeing Los Angeles, and this here story I'm about to unfold, well, I guess I seen somethin' every bit as stupefyin' as you'd see in any of them other places. And in English, too. So I can die with a smile on my face, without feelin' like the good Lord gypped me.

  Now this here story I'm about to unfold took place back in the early '90s - just about the time of our conflict with Sad'm and the I-raqis. I only mention it because sometimes there's a man... I won't say a hero, 'cause, what's a hero? But sometimes, there's a man. And I'm talkin' about the Dude here. Sometimes, there's a man, well, he's the man for his time and place. He fits right in there. And that's the Dude, in Los Angeles. And even if he's a lazy man - and the Dude was most certainly that. Quite possibly the laziest in Los Angeles County, which would place him high in the runnin' for laziest worldwide. But sometimes there's a man, sometimes, there's a man. Aw. I lost my train of thought here. But... aw, hell. I've done introduced him enough

Jeff Bridges slacks like no other!  John Goodman is Carl, a crazy-ass, funny, bipolar megalomaniac that is always making himself feel like someone important, taking charge of the Duder's uninvited, misguided adventures.  This plunges the Dude in even deeper and darker trouble than even he deserves, when Nigelist's mistake Bridges for the prominent, wealthy, philanthropist, that share identical names; Jeffery Labowski!  But Bridges keeps drinking Carl's Krazy Koolaide, regretting his militant bowling buddy's reckless involvement, every time.  The third-wheel, in this trio of lost, California-dreaming, lucky losers, is Steve Buscemi.  He plays Donnie, a lonely but lovable bowling Buddy, who is continually the target of Carl's lambasting, "SHUT THE F*** UP, DONNIE!", every time Donnie tries to add to the trio's conversations; which are usually an exchange of hilariously opposing views of mindless, meandering intercourse of the current state of affairs.  This twisted, but totally hilarious, case of mistaken identity, written by one Cohen brother and directed by the other, is CLASSIC COHEN BROTHER'S, bust yer gut laughing fare!  Filmed, IMHO, with trademark Cohen Brother's quirky, dark, contrasting, film noire style moodiness, intertwined with the ever-changing, Cohen Brother like camera angles, usually shot from first-person point of view, that the Cohen Brother's are now famous for!  I suppose, being biased as I am (I love everyone of their movies) influence my review of their efforts.  But, you can't argue against the pile of awards, including those gold, statuesque ones, they have amassed since Blood Simple came out, many moons ago?
  There are too many other, very talented, as well as famous, actors/actresses in Labowski.  I also love Jeff Bridges.  Always have, always will!
So, if you are in the mood for a great dark comedy to stream on the Amazon Fire Box/Stick, on that 3D 4K 70" OLED Flat Screen, you recently aquired from Amazon Prime, tonight and have never been on a trip in the Dude's world of easy, laid back, unemployed, blunt burnin' bowling and leisure, my suggestion?  Let the Dude abide......  You'll enjoy the ride.....!
P.S.......  Weird, crazy, coincidence?  I reside in Fargo "Yea, ya betcha" North Dakota.  The Cohen Brothers grew up in Minnesota.  Their, Oscar worthy (congrat's Marge!) film, "Fargo", was not shot in Fargo (not one frame), the opening scene was shot 90 miles north, in Grand Forks, there are scenes in Brainard, MN and Minn/St. Paul, MN.  The actress who plays, used car salesman, Jerry Lundegaard's wife, grew up and lives in Fargo.  I met her at a local T.C.B.Y., wow...  That was over 20 yrs ago.  In "The Big Lebowski" they mention a relative that lives in Moorhead, MN, which is Fargo's sister city.  The Red River divides them.  And, finally, Jeff Bridges' wife is from Fargo!  They frequent the city to visit her mother, who still lives here, I believe.  Many "Dude" sightings at the local West Acres Mall.
Happy streaming..........

I am a huge fan of the Coen brothers:  Raising AZ (15+), O Brother (12+) and No Country (4+) are movies I have watched several times (est by the numbers listed with each movie).  Big Lebowski was just not good.  In fact, it was stupid.  Perhaps IF I had finished watching it would have become a great movie, but it was just too much like my memory of "Dumb and Dumber."
The complete and utter overuse of the "F" bomb made the movie all the worse, all the more boorish.  Now, before you "Awww, man" please realize I tried.  I watched for over an hour.  Goodman, who I loved in the other Coen movies, was just so overly simplistic and stupid.  Of course, so was Bridges.
I am struggling right now to remember what the plot was.  It was just stupid.  I stopped watching because it became apparent to me that investing any more time into this crappy movie was a bad investment.  I laughed out loud 2-3 times, but by an hour I could have belly laughed 10x that with the other Coen movies I like.
Don't waste your time.

The Big Lebowski is a perfect movie.  It is a Coen Brothers movie, which means there will be some squeamish moments for those with sensitive feelings, but, the story is amazing!  It is a story of mistaken identity gone way, way wrong.

I've seen many, no all, of the Coen Brothers.  I think this has to be my favorite, closely followed by Fargo.  What makes this film so great is the endurance and quiet optimism that the Dude never seemed to lose.  His world revolves around bowling.  He seems to have no obvious means of supporting himself, but who am I to judge?  There are a number of small, but altogether delightful, little moments with cameos that on your first viewing may pass by without notice.  But, these cuties give us big clues about our character's development and come back later in the story as answers to big questions they posed originally.

Watch the movie!  Find out why the Dude abides!

This was the only Coen Brothers film that I have ever actually enjoyed (I know). The rug really *did* tie the room together, and I thank this film for introducing me to the Kenny Rogers & the First Edition Song, "Just Dropped In (to See What Condition My Condition Was In)." Great song that I probably would have never heard otherwise. The movie has its over-the-top moments that make it great, and if only we could all approach life from The Dude's perspective, the world would make a much more lackadaisic place. Bridges' performance makes you feel like he didn't have to stray too hard from his actual personality in order to play the part, and the relationship between Goodman and Buscemi is just hysterical.
Superb  acting  showing great depictions of aging 60s characters (2 stars ), fine  cinematography of  downscale L.A. (2 stars ).  Story  didn't meet  my expectations for a  Coen Bros pic.

Funniest movie I've ever seen.  Endlessly quotable, and works on different levels.  On the surface it is an old fashioned Raymond Chandler crime story, updated for the slacker 90s, but it is also a brilliant take on Nietzsche's "Last Man."  The Dude, played with stony casualness by Jeff Bridges, tries his best to not be involved, to not care, and to not participate in life, but is sucked in anyway by a weird combination of crime and mistaken identity.  Essentially, the Dude wants his floor rug, which was stolen by nihilists, to be replaced because, as he gently puts it, "It really tied the room together."  His buddy, Walter Sobchak (John Goodman at the height of his powers), is a damaged Vietnam veteran who is more than willing to enter the fray.  The rules are important to Walter.  We learn this when he pulls a pistol on bowling league compatriot Smokey (Jimmie Dale Gilmore) for crossing the line (literally) during league play.  "Smokey this is not 'Nam.  This is bowling.  There are rules."  And when Walter learns that the guys who stole the Dude's rug--the film's inciting incident--are nihilists, the game is really on.  "Say what you want about the tenets of National Socialism, Dude, at least it's an ethos."  One of my favorite aspects of the plot is that we never do find out where the Dude's rug is.  It doesn't matter.

A good story with lots of profanity, some nudity, profuse use of the word "dude", "The Big Lebowski" was admittedly entertaining. It seems this movie was the inspiration for other movies such as "Dude, Where's My Car?" and borrowed a lot from "Dumb and Dumber".  "The Big Lebowski" is one of the best Cohen Brothers movies next to: "O Brother, Where Art Thou?", "Burn After Reading", "Inside Llewyn Davis", "Intolerable Cruelty", and possibly "A Serious Man". There were several scenes of comedic nature (as is usually typical in most Cohen Brothers movies), which were enjoyable. The main character (aka Jeff Lebowski or "The Dude") was righteous and seems to be a lovable "loser" who has a good conscience. Watch this movie for a good time :-)

Where before I found the Dude hapless and enjoyable, now I find him irresponsible and his friend Walter intolerable.  This movie has, I suppose, given me insight into the effect of about the last 15 years.  I am now more grim, and far less inclined to forgive or think funny the various stupidities and crazinesses so well acted by the players.  If you haven't watched this in over 10 years, try it again, just to see;  we all today have seen too many crazinesses end in real tragedies for some of the things we thought funny, then, to seem funny, now.

I had originally seen this movie as a teenager, where I found it somewhat entertaining. Now, a decade or so later and after hearing that it is supposed to be a cult classic, I figured I would give it another try to see if I could finally "see the wisdom". Unfortunately, I found it even less interesting this second time. Not only were practically none of the characters believable, but I could not relate with or really appreciate any of them. The only real wisdom I noticed in this film was that some characters (The Dude) live life blindly, using drugs and alcohol to blunt their worries, while other characters (most of the others in the film) actively try to use or exploit others without regard for harm caused. Such wisdom is given in much better delivery in countless other movies out there. Hence, I cannot see the value in this film.

I am 65 yrs. old, grew up in PA, USA.  I moved to Phoenix, AZ, eventually S. CA in about 1970......The Big Lebowski is a brilliant script, brilliant acting, & one of the best movies every made!  I am someone who has watched LOTS of movies, & The Big Lebowski is my one of my rare favorites!.....I will also comment that if you didn't live in S. CA, or especially Orange County CA, you missed a UNIQUE social experience!  I am 65 now, & I have not only not been sorry for my time in S. CA, but I am happy to lived in those crazy  times!......The point is that the movie "Big Lebowski made me laugh nearly out of control!.....If you are conservative, did not experience a similar life in my times, etc., you may not enjoy the movie, but if you think some parts of your life, political philosophy, etc.line up, rent or buy the movie & prepared to be entertained!  Maureen

The Dude Abides. If you've not seen this movie, watch it tonight. If you've seen it years ago, watch it again. It is a pitch perfect comedy and seeing it again after all these years and all the failed wars in the middle east, you'll see it with new eyes. Walter is the US of A. He means well but everything he tries to do to help ends in yet another disaster. Witness our continuing debacles in Iraq and Afghanistan and Yemen and Somalia. We have great intentions, as does Walter, but our soul is the Dude and it just doesn't work out that well for the Dude or Walter.

The 1998 Coen brothers masterpiece "The Big Lebowski" starts off with 'The Dude' (Jeff Bridges) getting his carpet urinated on by one of two rogues who break into his "house" looking for money, thus starting off one of the most memorable cinematic rides I have ever witnessed. From 'The Dude's humorous caveats to his slightly psychotic friend Walter (John Goodman) to his various attempts to extricate himself from a kidnapping mystery involving a paralyzed man of the 1 percent (David Huddleston), his feminist daughter (Julianne Moore), and a film director (Ben Gazzara) looking for money from the Big Lebowskis wife (Tara Reid). Through it all, however, The Dude maintains a lovable, stoner attitude and delivers a series of one liners which shall remain forever engraved into your cerebrum. One of the films greatest assets, however, is it's interpolation of elements of film noir, which gives the film a darker edge, evidenced by our leading character's friend Donny (Steve Buscemi) suffering a fatal heart attack. The movie never takes itself to seriously, though, and quickly returns to prime comedic form when Walter accidentally empties Donny's ashes from a Folger's tin onto The Dude. The movie culminates with a mysterious cowboy speaking fondly of The Dude, and hoping that we enjoyed the story. We certainly did, and with this movie and the Coen's other two masterpieces (the twisted "Fargo" and the brooding "No Country For Old Men," based on the riveting 2005 novel by Cormac McCarthy), it is clear that they should be ranked amongst cinema's great directors Stanley Kubrick, David Lynch, Martin Scorsese, Ingmar Bergman, Quentin Tarantino, Alfred Hithcock, and Tom Green.

A thought provoking exegesis of the inachievable American Dream in a post-Reagan economy.  Set in the early 1990s,it describes a southern California dystopia populated by three classes: the economically and politically disenfranchised who dissociate from their condition with drugs, cheap entertainment and adopting an affectation of disinterest in societal norms; the wealthy who only interact with the former insofar as necessary to effect their selfish and sociopathic desires; and a servile class to the rich who are their patrons, a servile class who enforce their laws, fight their wars and/or facilitate the self-serving schemes.

Balzac suggested that behind every great fortune lies a great crime.  Sometimes that great crime begins by pissing on a guy's rug.

"Donny was a good bowler, and a good man. He was one of us. He was a man who loved the outdoors... and bowling, and as a surfer he explored the beaches of Southern California, from La Jolla to Leo Carrillo and... up to... Pismo. He died, like so many young men of his generation, he died before his time. In your wisdom, Lord, you took him, as you took so many bright flowering young men at Khe Sanh, at Langdok, at Hill 364. These young men gave their lives. And so would Donny. Donny, who loved bowling. And so, Theodore Donald Karabotsos, in accordance with what we think your dying wishes might well have been, we commit your final mortal remains to the bosom of the Pacific Ocean, which you loved so well.
Good night, sweet prince."

OK, this is probably not an unbiased review because I am a Big Lebowski fan from way back. This is my second favorite movie of all time. If you love the Coen brothers, you will like this movie. As if everyone on earth hasn't seen it.
If cursing isn't your thing, don't bother. They drop the F bomb a lot. In fact, one of my favorite lines is where Sam Elliott says to The Dude, "You curse too much," and The Dude replies, "What the f*** you talkin' about?"
I saw an interview with Jeff Bridges where he said whenever he happens upon this movie while channel surfing, he watches it, and he said, "That was some good work," or something like that. John Goodman and (RIP) Philip Seymour Hoffman, Julianne Moore, Steve Buscemi, and believe it or not, Ben Gazarra all turned in stellar performances.
You MUST see this movie.

Great comedy. This film is full of great actors portraying characters that will have you rolling. I know people like this and I believe everyone knows a person that acts as a character in this film. Jeff Bridges plays "The Dude", a pot smoking, drinking, lazy hippie that gets mixed up in a problem that belongs to another person with the same name of Jeff Lebowski and it gets crazier from there. His story to sort out this issue involves characters that help and hinder him on his path to clear up this mishap. As he tries to clear his name and get restitution for his rug we are introduced to the rest of this films great characters. I recommend watching this if you are in the mood to laugh. John Turturro's character Jesus is great. All few minutes he is in the movie is a treat... John Goodman is a nut that is a gun totting bowling maniac. Steve Buscemi is a timid bowler on the team made up of John Goodman and Jeff Bridges.

An amazing piece of cinema. I first saw this sneaking into a movie theater with friends when I as 16. There was basically no one in the room and I was sprawled out across several seats. I remember thinking "this is funny" but in a way that was consistent and deeper than "haha." At that age, I couldn't put my finger on it but the movie appeals to my philosophical sensibilities. It is rich and layered in a way that makes repeat watching a treat. As Lebowski is a man for his time and place, the chronicling of this tale is was certainly for its time and place. It will live on and I hope it will continue to be a window into the journey of self exploration.

I've seen it so many times I don't know why I don't just buy a copy.  The first time I saw this was long ago.  I really didn't get it until I started taking film classes.  Then I found that this film had a cult following.  People went to screenings in bathrobes.  What I finally understood about "the Dude" is that he is everything you'd dislike about a lazy, dope smoking, Caucasian drinking, throw-back from the 60s but is likable none the less because all he ever wants is his rug back.  Can you really fault him for that?  Five stars.

Jeff Bridges IS The Dude, a laid back citizen of la la land. His breakfast is a White Russian and a joint, (just like a roommate I had in Ocean Beach, Ca).  His sidekick Walter, played by John Goodman, isn't laid back at all.  He is a Vietnam Vet who thinks he's still over there.  Mistaken identity, extortion, double-dealing, and swindling  keep the action and hilarity moving right through to the end.  Of course The Dude prevails.

This movie should be included in any list of the top 25 comedies, certainly of the Last Millennium, or the top 100 movies ever. Obviously, Jeff Bridges had to be at the top of his game, but Every character is well-realized and acted by this all-star cast, including Steve Buscemi, John Goodman, John Turturro, Julianne Moore, David Huddleston, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, Tara Reid, Sam Elliott, Peter Stormare, - How did the Coen Brothers amass such a wealth of talent for this film? - and a host of others, all giving transcendent performances.  Anyway, this movie takes a case of mistaken-identity to sublimely ridiculous extremes, all the while slyly injecting social commentary into the narrative - speaking of which, Elliott's intermittent narration of the story lends just the right tone.  I don't think it's possible to say much about this film without ruining the expository fun of seeing the plot's - and the screenplay's developments.  The droll dialogue is intrinsic to the hilarity and overall feel of this great American classic film...

This is arguably the best dialog driven movie ever made. The character acting is flawless. This movie drives the point that actors should not wait their turn to speak their lines, speaking over each other is how people talk in reality. You need to watch the movie more than once. I saw this movie the day it was released in the movie theaters and hated it. A year later I purchased the Lazer Disc, (I collect movies even if I don't like them) I watched the movie at least 100 times after that and each time I found the individual characters doing hysterically funny gestures in the background. The character in focus is not always the actor you should be paying attention too. The acting will have you in stitches. Enough said, watch it once and laugh a little, watch it multiple times and be prepared for your face to cramp from laughter and smiling. If you like the art of movie making, there is nothing more intricate, detailed and well funny. To date, I have studied this movie over a thousand times.

I'm still not sure how to characterize this film, so I'll try to keep it short and sweet, but with this film, I don't think I can.

To the outright disgust of many people I've talked to about it, I'm maintaining this is a pretty mediocre science-fiction film. Give me a chance to explain it to you without boring you to death like the other endless gushing/hating reviews.

"The Stranger" (Sam Elliott) narrates throughout, and even his introduction tells you right off the bat this is HIS story, and it's his re-telling of it: "Now this here story I'm about to unfold took place back in the early '90s - just about the time of our conflict with Saddam and the Iraqis."

His main focus, however, is on Jeff "The Dude" Lebowski (Jeff Bridges). Now seeing as how the film was written about that time and filmed in late 1997, why use a cowboy to narrate this film? Because he is a traveler, a literal stranger to the entire film, therefore he has no name and is as removed from the rest of the cast as anyone else could be. Everyone else is from that time, singularly and with a linear time line and time frame.

(It's interesting that a copy of "Being and Nothingness" by French existentialist Jean-Paul Sartre is on his nightstand near his bed, a remind
er by the Coen Brothers that all of this is nothing, and empty exercise, all created by nothing and going back to nothing. Sartre also wrote a novel titled "The Stranger," about confusion, unresolved feelings and sexual confusion between men and women.)

At one point The Stranger even decides to step in twice: halfway during the movie for a one minute interaction with The Dude at the bar in the bowling alley, to quickly compliment him and to chastise him ("Do you have to use so many cuss words?"), then easy as a summer breeze leaves the frame. In another 1 minute sequence he quickly appears and is happy for The Dude and even goes so far to say take it easy, and then says "I know that you will," to which The Dude says "The Dude abides," then walks away.

It leaves The Stranger to end the film with a monologue about the future, how "the human comedy keeps perpetuating itself," "across the sands of time until we..." and then he stops himself. And with that, the film is over.

To be honest, the rest of the film in between the beginning and the end is a farce of sorts, and as the Coen Brothers have said in some interviews it's a tribute of sorts to Raymond Chandler's "The Big Sleep," about double-crossing, the abuse of power and the sudden introductions of absurd characters for distraction purposes. The Dude and his friend Walter (John Goodman) go a little overboard on these points, but it's understandable.

This story is for the benefit of The Stranger, who as the narrator has told it his way, and is relaying it to an audience who accepts his version as the truth. It seems he has told the story before to others and is fascinated with character of The Dude, almost to the point of it being a worship. He even says at the end "It made me laugh to meet the man."

Is The Stranger a metaphor and nothing more? Is there a religious theme? Is The Dude a modern-day God and his "little Lebowski on the way" on the way his "only begotten son" by a woman who has obvious father issues?

It can be said yes, and no, and both, but I still maintain at the center of the film is The Stranger, a Sartre-created no one, to take the whole of the story and shift it and tell it as he sees it, as if only an time traveler could tell it, as only someone who can back up and look at it over and over. Is he from the future, or the past? Does he purposely take on the persona of the American cowboy as the honest hero, to symbolize he is really telling a great story? In the end, does it matter?

Time travel or not, this story leaves a lot more questions than answers, no matter how linear and simple the tale is told, there are so many scenes within the film which almost make zero sense (his hallucinations, the introduction of the German minimalist/porn stars) but within the context of the telling by The Stranger simply work.

There are many versions out there, on DVD, on Blu-Ray, some good, some bad, and apparently a 10th Anniversary "bowling ball" case version sucks, so avoid that.

What matters is that you open your mind to what may be one of the most mediocre time-travel movies ever made or an amazing retro romanticist/drama/comedy you've ever looked at. I'll stay with my explanation, it makes the absurdity easier to swallow.

The Fabulous Cohen Boys give Jeff Bridges the role of a lifetime as The Dude (or His Dudeness, or Duder, or El Duderino, if you're not into that whole brevity thing), a slobbish pothead bowler who reluctantly gets hired as courier in a millionaire's wife kidnaping. In true Marlowesque fashion, while doing the job he encounters several strange characters, including nymphos, heiresses, pimps, cholos, nazis, nihilists, walkiries, yes-men, cowboys, gangsters, cops, private eyes, Vietnam vets, conceptual artists, chorus girls, dead guys, and a Johnson-eating marmot! I had to see it twice, for I was laughing so hard to catch it all the first time! Great all-star cast to boot! Don't miss it!

To understand the sense of what now follows requires you watch the movie.

Of course The Dude abides. A bigger Lebowski is to be had in the other. Bunny Lebowski's presence is the catalyst for the action, whose actions merely spoken of in the story coincidentally brings the two (or maybe it's three...no it's four) Lebowskis together. Another Lebowski, the daughter of the bigger Lebowski, regards The Dude (and it's The Dude and not just Dude) for what ultimately only his gender, and his social-economic situation, can provide her. She values The Dude for what he can donate.

The Big Lebowski's story chronicles The Dude's experience in a world all so familiar yet all so unlike his own. His misadventures might be regarded his ventures into and through an inconsequential world (an underworld) from which he exits the same condition as he entered. For The Dude accepts both worlds, for The Dude abides. In either world The Dude seems to lose nothing for he has nothing to lose except a rug located in the living room ties everything together. Ironically, its absence is the unraveling of The Dude's daily routine. In short order The Dude obtains another rug to replace the other. All things measure and weigh equally for The Dude. Hence, in life The Dude seems to find a sweet-spot of things equaling out for him.

It's hard to say this movie is great because of the Cohen brother's talent or that of Jeff Bridges. Without a doubt both the Cohen's talent and Bridges is the reason for this movie to be ironically American. Besides, undoubtedly The Bid Lebowski is one of the best American ( or even foreign) made cinemas to date, maybe for ever.

To not see The Bid Lebowski is to remain ignorant of one of the many prominent cultural icons of our day.

I think everyone has had people in their life highly recommend movies, especially movies like The Big Lebowski. So, you go in with high expectations and perhaps that was my issue. I have to start this off by saying, I LOVE the cast - Steve Buscemi is a favorite of mine, through and through. But it wasn't enough. A lot of the funny parts felt forced, to me. I read some of the other negative reviews and it seems like, for most, they had issues with the swearing. I definitely don't have that problem. This just felt flat and stale. The best parts were the jokes regarding the big Lebowski and the Dude's shared name and the "lady friend" bit. John Goodman is a wonderful actor, but the character ... It felt like he was just reading a script. I will say that for the most part, Jeff Bridges did portray his character well. John Turturro looks stellar in those pants, but I had questions as to why they gave his character as much background as they did without him really being necessary to the movie. I could just be taking too much, too hard of a look at the movie and/or perhaps my sense of humor got shot off somewhere, but this was not a film for me.

Finally, I watched the Big Lebowski movie and I know why my husband's, "the Dude abides" statement is great! I loved this movie! My husband and I aren't sure whether a younger generation would find it funny, or get it at all. And we really aren't sure if a person who has never gotten high would appreciate it. But having enjoyed the 70s, we also enjoyed this movie. I never lost touch with who I was in the 70s but it truly felt like everybody else had turned their backs on it by the time we reached the 90s. They became responsible Republican citizens who had never touched a drug in their life. Ok, some of them still got high after the kids were in bed... So, to know that the Dude still abides is great news to us from the 70s. He tokes on, despite the changes around him. Vietnam is still acknowledged. The movie is a funny movie that is clearly a 5 for us. I truly hope it is a 5 for younger people and non drug users because I would take that to mean that the Dude really does abide. We would be able to say, " you're seriously cool, man," to the kids raised to think the pursuit of money was the meaning of life, and who would have expected that?

There is not much more that I can add to others' reviews, but I'll try. The concept -- SoCal noir detective story crossed with stoner movie -- is inspired. The (comedic) execution of this big little movie is brilliant because, of course, it's the Coen Brothers. The cast are all total professionals who, you can tell, are totally committed and utterly believable despite the farcical aspects of the story. Everyone in this movie is ALL IN. That is what makes The Big Lebowski both so great and also so hilarious -- and also surprisingly touching at certain points. The soundtrack is legendary. The visuals are striking. It's a bit over the top at times, but that's part of its charm. Nothing here is wasted; every scene is included for a reason. It's high art and high farce indie film like you've never seen before.

The writing is razor sharp and the direction skillfully navigates between noir and quirky, yet it's totally professional and elevates the entirety to high (farcical) art. Many veteran Coen actors are here, yet in roles like you've never seen them before. The Big Lebowski makes me wonder what Clay Pigeons would have been like, had the Coens directed it. And you don't have to be stoned to enjoy The Big Lebowski -- it is fantastically hilarious, sober or altered.

You owe it to yourself to watch this. Try to forget the hype of it from every Big Lebowski fan who's ever urged you to watch it before you view it, though, or you may be underwhelmed the first time. That being said, it bears repeat viewing -- again and again and again. It just gets better each time -- and with repeat viewings you'll catch the many great lines you didn't hear the first (or third or fifth) time because you were laughing too hard.

If you don't already know this film is a classic and hilarious no need to read further. But if you're interested in the current Bluray edition it's strictly a stop gap until they improve the resolution. They used a very aggressive DNR processing which takes out small imperfections in the film's appearance in favor of reduced detail, more homogenous colors and a flatter more 2 -D picture. Read the DVDBeaver review for more details. This edition will do in a pinch but if you've already got the movie hold out for a better edition which I guarantee you is coming.

The Big Lebowski (1998) represents the Coen brothers at their hilarious best. It may lack the metaphysical gravitas of Fargo (1995) and the much later No Country For Old Men (2007), but unlike the anarchic and more slapstick Raising Arizona (1987), the outrageous stream of jokes and comic fantasies clearly add up to something - namely a parable on friendship and specifically male camaraderie in a cold hostile world otherwise gone to the dogs. This links the film to Howard Hawks whose greatest films (Only Angels Have Wings [1939], Red River [1948] and Rio Bravo [1959]) are all variations on the same theme. More to the point is The Big Lebowski's relationship with Hawks' The Big Sleep (1946) (joke ref: The Big Sleep/Lebowski - Geddit?) and to the world of Raymond Chandler in general. Enter Jeff "the Dude" Lebowski as the comic alter-ego of Humphrey Bogart's Philip Marlowe. As the convoluted story involving murder, drugs, prostitution, kidnapping and all things noir strangulates to the point of complete confusion Bogart's Marlowe keeps his head above everything and emerges untarnished to save the day. Elliot Gould's laid-back Marlowe in Robert Altman's ironic and iconic debunking revisionist neo-noir The Long Goodbye (1973) (just like his twin J. J. Gittes in Chinatown from the following year) gets everything wrong and ends up not even being able to save himself. Jeff Bridges' even more laid-back hippy take on the same character gets everything wrong without even knowing what he is supposed to get right in the first place. Over the 2-hour duration of the film his car is stolen, then wrecked, then completely destroyed; his apartment is broken into, then wrecked, then completely destroyed; his person is beaten up, then drugged, then almost completely destroyed. And yet somehow, the Dude confounds the odds and gets to 'abide' another day, and unlike either The Big Sleep or The Long Goodbye, The Big Lebowski leaves us feeling ill at the end through having laughed so much on the journey.

Don't get me wrong, the Dude is no Private Dick. In fact he's a complete slacker, an unemployed left-over from the 60s who wastes his life hanging around chewing the fat with his bowling buddies. They are the meek and mild and none-to-bright Donny (Steve Buscemi who spends the movie being told to shut up without actually saying much - joke ref to the motor-mouth character he played in Fargo) and the aggressive neurotic Vietnam vet with an attitude dysfunction Walter Sobchak (John Goodman in effing and blinding grandstanding form twinned with his role in Barton Fink [1991] - The Big Lebowski was written at that time). The Dude's redeeming quality is his essentially good nature rendered super-cool by an effortless zoned-out marijuana-high performance from Bridges. His great misfortune is his name which he shares with another Jeffrey Lebowski who a gang of intruders come looking for at the beginning of the film. The poor Dude gets beaten up and when they realize they have the wrong man they urinate on his rug as well. Egged on by his self-righteous and trouble-making buddy Walter, the Dude goes to the other Lebowski's house which turns out to be a mansion (think Bogey visiting the Sternwoods at the beginning of The Big Sleep). We meet Lebowski's assistant (an effete Philip Seymour Hoffman) and Lebowski himself (David Huddleston) who turns out to be a millionaire Korean vet. Wheelchair-bound (just like Mr. Sternwood), he dismisses the Dude as a bum. The Dude takes a rug anyway and on his way out meets Lebowski's young model trophy wife (Tara Reid) who offers to blow him for a thousand bucks - "I'll just go to the cash machine", he says on leaving. Turns out the girl is kidnapped and Lebowski recalls the Dude wanting to hire him as bagman. From here the plot spirals into The Big Sleep-like labyrinthine complexity, which is OK 'cos the plot's not important anyway (so say the Coens). This turns out to be a disingenuous disclaimer (one of many MacGuffins), the film's best feature turning out to be its extraordinarily inventive story-telling.

What initially seizes the attention here is the gallery of Fellini/Pynchon-esque grotesques that parade before us as we play the 'spot-the-star' game. There's Julianne Moore in the Lauren Bacall role as a vaginal visual artist who makes a spectacular nude entrance swinging on a trapeze. Her clearly enunciated Brit-accent English is a joke ref to another contemporary film (this time The End of the Affair). There's John Turturro as Jesus Quintana, a perverted child molester of Cuban extraction who performs to camp excess as he polishes his balls and struts in front of the Dude and his gang (check out those pelvic thrusts, man!) in the bowling alley. Then there's David Thewlis (virtually unrecognizable) as a hyper-ventilating 'video artist' with a fit of the giggles, Jon Polito as a down-at-heel gumshoe, Peter Stormare as one of three Nazi/Nihilists who speaks with the affected cod-German accent he used on the set of Fargo (but who never actually said anything on screen during that film), Ben Gazzara as a rich silky-smooth pornographer introduced at a Malibu beach house party via a bare-breasted trampoline artist (dig the gossamer balls there, man!) to the Henry Mancini song "Lujon". Finally, there's Sam Elliot playing an old cowboy who offers the traditional Raymond Chandler third-party perspective on the whole narrative and who gets to voice straight to camera the film's moral.

The film's mise-en-scne is cued by the main setting, the bowling alley, and as we travel through the various strata of L. A. society (another Chandler feature) trying to keep up with the Dude and his adventures everything is shot (by Coen regular Roger Deakins) to be plasticky and bright with a well chosen (by T-Bone Burnett) playlist of rock songs mainly from the 60s ranging from Creedence Clearwater Revival through to Captain Beefheart, Moondog, Bob Dylan, the Stones and to a Gipsy Kings' cover version of `Hotel California'. Most bizarrely entertaining of all are fantasy sequences covering the many occasions the Dude is knocked out, drugged and otherwise abused, the best of them being a huge dance number referencing Busby Berkeley, the Powell-Pressburger stairway to Heaven from A Matter of Life and Death (1946 - the same year as The Big Sleep!), and many more as the Dude sails down a bowling lane beneath the spread legs of showgirls with a ridiculous grin on his face as we hear "Just Dropped in (to See What Condition My Condition Was In)" by Kenny Rogers. Much of the comic inspiration here is inspired (too inspired to be spoiled by me relating it all to you) and there's even a possible allegory of the then-current Gulf War lying within much of what Walter says and a guest appearance by Sadam Hussein himself. Oh, and there's an extremely moving cliff-top funeral oration that will have you crying...

The Big Lebowski plays bright, fast, furious and doesn't bother much with believability, but when the crowd has moved on and the shouting is over we are left with a man whose life was made difficult by his buddies (especially Walter), but who learns that without them he would be no different from the rest of the selfish money-grubbing characters we meet throughout the film. In fact without his friends he would be nothing at all.

The film wasn't successful when it first came out, but it has since garnered cult status as have many of the Coens' films. They are without doubt alongside Terrence Malick America's pre-eminent film-makers today. Martin Scorsese might surprise us in the future with something fresh, but I guess his best years (and films) are well behind him now. P. T. Anderson is another director to reckon with and his up-coming Thomas Pynchon adaptation Inherent Vice may well provide direct comparison with The Big Lebowski. We will see...

Okay I admit when I saw this movie back when it was in the theatres, I didn't get it. Everybody loves this movie. When you asked them what's the morale or theme of the story, they won't know. They'll try to explain and you'll lose interest. The Coen bros have proved they are the biggest nihilist in cinema. This movie is their last swan song before really getting mired down in heavy god-less movie making whereby you want to slit your wrists after leaving the theatre: "No Country for Old Men" I'm looking in your direction. The Big Lebowski still has a little hope for humanity, a little understanding that it's okay to be loser, as long as you are still decent to people. But why is the character Jesus in there? Why bother with a narrator? is their a character arc to the hero? Probably not. The Coen bros never read Joseph Campbell. Maybe that's okay for this movie. But in my opinion, for the Coen Bros. This is like Doris Lessing's novel: "Briefing for a Descent into Hell"

All films after it are part of that descent...

Perhaps one of the best straight-out performances of Jeff Bridges and John Goodman, ever.  Joel and Ethan Cohen really allow an incredible cast to just ACT and it comes through in a movie that I am sure has exceeded the expectations of everyone involved.  With a great, wandering plot and a number of infamous one liners, TBL is a must-see for Achievers (and proud we are of all of them) and non-Achievers alike.  One of the best aspects of this movie is that it is a top rate production where you get that small, independent film feel despite, or possibly IN-spite of the big production backing. The references and one-liners have led to a cult following vis-a-vis www.dudeism.com, and simultaneously speak on an Animal House level and as far as you want to take it philosophically.  A lotta ins, lotta outs, a lotta what have you.  A technicolor neo-noir.  You can overthink it or just enjoy it for the patent excellence it demonstrates.  ...  I mean, thats like, my opinion, Man.

This movie is full of good moments, and I can see why it's a beloved cult classic for that reason. But as a story--even a goofy, comical one--it's lacking. Lacking it's whole second half, the way it feels. Or at least it's climax and closure.

I was engrossed in the story, and the weird goofy atmosphere; and then, suddenly, the movie just ended. Ended right after a rather gut-wrenching scene which--while beautifully done--wasn't nearly relevant enough to justify being the cilmax (if that's what it was supposed to be). And then they skip right to the closing scene, before the audience has had any time to get over this character's death, while acting as if it's ending on an uplifting note. I don't object to a lovable supporting character dying; but you can't just end the movie with that, at least not with this type of story. The death would have worked fine had it happened earlier in the movie--even just a few scenes earlier--but on the final note? It was left-field, both in terms of the plot and the movie's tone.

I *do* recommend this movie to fans of Steve Buscemi and John Goodman, as well as fans of weird cult movies. But, don't get your hopes up for anything fantastic. Expect to have fun for two hours, and then suddenly get a slap in the face.

I saw this movie advertised 14 years ago, and I read some favorable reviews more recently.  Finally, seeing it for sale for $5, I bought it.  I spent two hours watching this cruddy flick; it was two hours wasted.

It's a movie about a worthless slacker, an unemployed druggie (Lebowski, alias the Dude) who is the prey of several groups of gangsters because of a case of mistaken identity.  The Big Lebowski is a phony tycoon married to a jailbait tramp.

None of the characters are worth a damn, except for a mysterious stranger, played by Sam Elliot, who shows up now and then to make pithy comments.  The story goes nowhere, and the Dude ends up not much worse for the wear, but no better either, at the end of the two hours.  Michelangelo Antonioni did this sort of thing better in 1966 with Blow-Up.

Save your $5 and save two hours of your life.  Remember that your time is limited; once it is wasted, you will never get it back.

I just don't get the hype for this movie. It's weird, but mostly just not very funny. I bought it because it was about as cheap to buy as rent. I'd heard about it for years & years, and after recently seeing another reference to it, wanted to see the movie to understand the references. It turns out, we had actually seen this in the past, but just didn't remember because it's not very good, much less funny. Mostly weird. Maybe it only makes sense if you're high.

Their reasons being:  "I hate the way the people dress in this movie", or, "This is just a bunch of people acting stupid..."

Which, come to think of it, are a couple of the reasons I hate the whole "Real Housewives" thing on tv...

But really, what people who raise these objections don't get, (and as we know, "That's just your opinion, man.")is, if you look at this movie beyond the surface, the comedy, the bad clothes, what you have is an old school, Raymond Chandler style detective story.

This is a solid storyline, man, and all the other stuff wouldn't work if you didn't have that to pull the whole movie together.

Not Coen&Coen at their best, but even on an off-year, they still do passably.  The story itself is amusing, clever, unpredictable - but as "the Stranger" points out, "too many curse words," as in, every 3rd word is the F-word, and it's overkill.  Aside from that (and it's not easy to overlook, unless you happen to talk that way yourself, in which case: get therapy), the story and the acting are fine, and, typically of Coen&Coen, we really do believe these slobs actually exist.  Thanks to the main character, "the Dude," being a stoner, we get a few dream/fantasy sequences, which seem to be spoofing both MTV and the lavishly choreographed musicals of the 1930s.  We meet NO nice people in this universe, just cuckoos and losers - but, at times the movie is almost like a Christian sermon: there are no "losers" in God's universe, even the stoners and nut cases deserve a little sympathy.  John Goodman steals the show as the warped (but amazingly charismatic and masculine) Vietnam Vet, Walter, but it was funny seeing a few familiar faces from the old days, like David Huddleston and Ben Gazzara. Julianne Moore has a funny (and menacing) role as a slightly cracked artiste, John Turturro is creepy in a brief but highly memorable turn as a Hispanic bowler (and pedophile).  Red herrings are present (typical Coen&Coen), and the scene with kid and the red Corvette is a hoot.  What a shame that the improv feel of the whole thing resulted in an overly generous use of obscenity.  Coen&Coen can write very smart dialogue, so they can do better than this.

Not in the same league as Fargo or the endearing O Brother, Where Art Thou?, but it's watchable - you'll either turn it off after 10 minutes, or watch the whole thing (while keeping the kids out of the room, unless they hear the F-word from you all the time, in which case: shame on you).

This is a truly horrible movie and a huge disappointment!  I expected so much better from the producers of Fargo.  Jeff Bridges does nothing worthwhile.  John Goodman is a foul-mouthed bully - totally unlikable.  Julianne Moore is such a major disappointment with a truly weird role.  I wish I had never seen her in this movie.  She is one of my favorite actresses, but this role is so over-the-top and unattractive.  I always look forward to anything Steve Buscemi does, but he had almost no role whatsoever.  How did they manage to make him boring?  The funniest and best roles/actors in the entire film were the supporting cast.  Phillip Seymour Hoffman is the best thing in the film.  He always gives a great performance.  The cops who took Jeff Bridges stolen car report, and the cop who gives the car back to him, are funny.  They are more impressive by far then any of the lead actors.  There is no plot, no humor, no dialogue, nothing to make this movie worth watching.  Sam Elliot said it all when he said they use the "f" word too much.  This movie would have been so much better with an actual scrip!  My husband and I actually walked out of the movie theatre 15 minutes before the end.  We have never done that before.  I am only sorry we didn't walk out 15 minutes after it began.  I am embarrassed I was there at all.  The actors should feel humiliated they were associated with this film.  I am just amazed the producers got away with it.  Obviously, they saved money by not having a script or a plot.  IT WAS TERRIBLE!

The Big Lebowski is an . . . odd film, to say the least, and thats pretty much universally agreed upon. The key element here is, then, does its oddness appeal to you personally? If it does, youll love this movie. If it doesnt, youll probably end up hating it, or at the least be very, very confused.

The Cohen brothers have a history of odd, artsy films that can be funny as well as confusing. This comedy (and it is a bit of a stretch to label it as such) is a cult-classic from 1998. It follows the story of Jeffery The Dude Lebowski, played by Jeff Bridges, an unemployed amateur bowler and professional slacker, as he gets mixed up in a complicated case of kidnapping and mistaken identity, among many other things. Trying to explain the narrative beyond that is a Herculean task in and of itself, as its complication surpasses even Dan Brown or Nolan levels. In one sense, its a slice-of-life tale about the Dude, but its a particularly strange slice here. A lot of things happen, not always related to each other or even in a logical sequence. That, though, is where most of the comedy comes in this film; the sheer oddity of the situations, the characters, and most importantly, those characters reactions to those situations.

I would not say that for me personally, that this film was hilarious, but I also wouldnt say it was terrible either, as I did laugh quite a bit during. This really is one of those films that is experienced and liked on a person-to-person basis. There is a lot here that is pointless: some characters, most dialogue, several scenes and sequences; all of which adds up to essentially nothing. But this films lack of a point is the point itself. This is great if this works for you, but disastrous if it doesnt.

Bridges is great as the Dude, and it was one of those performances where it was so good, it seems like it wasn't really acting and that is what the actor is really like. Hes likable in his own loserly way. John Goodman plays the Dudes best friend Walter, who is immediately unlikable; you wonder why the Dude puts up with him. The rest of the actors and characters, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, Julliane Moore, Tara Reid, Steve Buscemi, are all memorable in their own eccentricities but episodic in their appearances and unimportant in their significance. Again though, their pointlessness is their point. There are other good things to be had in this film. The cinematography is really good and creative in some spots, particularly in the dream sequences, which are arguably the best scenes in the film.

Its like I said, this film is best taken on an individual basis. I can see why some people like it, and I can also certainly see why some people hate it. Personally, I liked it well enough; I don't love it, and certainly wouldnt rank it among my favorite films or even comedies, but its far from terrible; it was entertaining enough to find amusing. You may like its strangeness and eccentricity; you may hate its pointlessness and unfocused narrative. You may love its memorable and quirky characters; you may hate its confusing structure. Take it at your own pace. Like it or not, either way, Im sure the Dude will abide.

Many people I recommended it as one of the best American films. I do not share this assessment at all. However, the film is entertaining, funny and has some very colorful characters. The performances are fine. An entertaining film.

I think more than anything else about "the Dude," it is his capacity to simply not give a s*** about the things that really don't matter that have earned him his cult following. These are uncertain times, and even were back when the Coen Brothers made this film in 1998. This film is a classic that has a cult following and a documentary film made about the phenomenon of The Big Lebowski "Achievers." This is fine directing that can be observed in the artistry of much of the camerawork, but especially in the larger than life unique and fascinating characters. John Goodman is at his best, and the scenes with John Tuturro's "Jesus" character are something not to be missed. The Big Lebowski is a guaranteed great time for just about anyone.

If anything, this movie seems more realistic and relevant today than it did when it was released. In particular, John Goodman's psychotic neo-con Walter has become a common sight in many parts of Amefican life and politics, and sadly, the tolerant, peaceful, and philisophical Dude has become even more of an endangered species than he was in the 90s. One of the Coen Brothers' most effective tricks is to present what are essentially stereotypes in a way that is both endearing and insightful (think about Margie from "Fargo", Brad Pitt's vane and ignorant character in "Burn After Reading", and everyone in "Oh, Brother..." and their brilliant early film "Blood Simple")-and to see how these characters evolve and function in their own cultural contexts. They humanize the stereotypes and make us recognize traces of ourselves in even the most outrageous. It wopuld be a good thing if more people were in touch with their "dudeness" and farther away from their Walterism.

The closest thing I can think of to "The Big Lebowski" is Wilde's "The Importance of Being Earnest." Both have things that look like plots . . . but plot isn't the point. They have things that look like characters who represent social types . . . but that isn't the point. They both tempt you to consider that they might be social satire . . . but that doesn't seem to explain their charm. What they are are aesthetic constructions that have their own rhythm and shape -- they don't "represent" anything -- and for that reason, they are much more like pieces of music or dance than anything else. Our involvement with them is wholly aesthetic, and the pleasures they afford are aesthetic pleasures -- the pleasures of appreciating a self-sustaining pattern. We don't "care" about the characters -- we enjoy watching them jump through the hoops of Joel and Ethan Coen's construction. The Coen brothers have always been prone to genre-bending and playing with expectations and conventions, but here they go the whole hog and cut themselves loose from representation altogether.

The film gives us hints about how we are to take it -- in the dream sequences (and don't tell me that they are to be taken seriously as representations of trips), in the formulaic, leitmotivic language of Walter (John Goodman) -- and don't tell me that his language is to be taken as a representation of a disturbed Vietnam vet -- in the totally abstract art of Maud (Julianne Moore), whose insistence that her art is "vaginal" is, of course, a joke, and in the visual leitmotivs of the bowling alley scenes. The figures of Jesus (John Turturro) and the Stranger (Sam Elliot) also are presented in ways that patently defy "realistic" representations of anything. Just ask yourself: where does the Stranger get his authority as a storyteller about a "story" set in modern LA, and you realize that that's a question that has no answer, because we're not in the world of questions and answers. Through all this shambles The Dude (Jeff Bridges), an anarchic spirit who simply points up the high artificiality of the cinematic context through which he shambles. He's as aimless and unrepresentative (and unemployed) as the young men in Wilde's play -- his "meaning" is simply what he contributes to the dance or tone-poem that is the film. With art this "pure" there are only two possible responses -- dismiss it as trivial because it's "unreal," or admit that ALL art is unreal at some level and just enjoy the kind of pleasure that art as art affords.

The Big Lebowski came to me hyped to the limit. So maybe that's why I was less than impressed. Yes, sure, it's a funny enough movie. Yes, it's not slick and might even be rough around the edges. Yes, it's pretty offbeat (though I found Raising Arizona more entertaining in this respect). Yes, it takes nothing (not even itself) seriously. Yes, it's pretty camp at times. Yes, it does not seem to try very hard in any aspect of film-making.

The whole thing sort of takes mediocrity (not in a bad sense) to a new level. And maybe that's part of its charm. I don't know. I'll have to watch it again when I get it back (everyone seems to want to borrow this thing). It apparently grows on you.
The Blu-ray transfer is done well and the booklet inside has lots of interesting extras; this is worth your money and time.

If you are into quirky comedies then chances are you'll appreciate the story. I've shown this film to some....um I guess you'd say...squares, who did not enjoy this film. This is a classic in my family, we rented from Amazon because we could not find the DVD.

I'm not sure why I kept putting off watching this movie. I missed it in the theaters. It's been available, I'm sure, for several years on Netflix and, now, Amazon. There are so many portrayals that just stick- John Goodman constantly putting Steve Buscemi down, John Toturro as Jesus, the purple suited bowler, Jeff Bridges, any scene he's in, Julianne Moore, for a role that would come off as oddball and misplaced in any other movie, but fits so well here, the send-off of Steve Buscemi from the Folger's urn. The thugs are frightening and inept. I'll probably watch it over time a few more times to try and figure out the plot, figure out where the scam is and why Jeff Bridges isn't bumped off. He's not even a lovable jerk, but the film is lovable. It might pay to watch it again to see if any clues are dropped about what these guys do for a living because, obviously, they don't work. It turns out that doesn't matter.

I have watched The Big Lebowski at least twenty five times.  I can drop in anywhere in the film for a few minutes and get many laughs. What else do you want me to say?

Full disclosure:  I've never seen The Big Lebowski before.

(pause for mocking laughter to subside).

I know, I know.  How can any self-respecting thirty-something actually admit to never having watching The Dude.  So, here's the deal.  I've never actually admitted that before.  I always smiled and laughed along whenever people mentioned the movie or quoted from its lines.  I always nodded knowingly whenever anyone referenced The Dude or 'What makes a man'.

IFC played this movie the other night and I decided that it was time for me to man up and watch.  See what all the fuss was about.

And I did.

Now, for anyone who wants a movie with a clearly delineated beginning, middle and end, this is not for you.  Try something with Kate Hudson, preferably under the title 'Rom-Com'.

No, this is for someone that just wants to be taken on a joyous, raucous ride with incredible talented performers.  Because that's really what John Goodman, Jeff Bridges and Steve Buscemi are in this movie.  Beyond mere actors reading lines they are performers, performing their roles.

'The Big Lebowski' has to be one of my favorite flicks but this is a disappointing and underwhelming Blu Ray presentation. Color is good but the picture just looks soft in HD - either the result of an uprez, grain reduction software (should be banned!), or latter generation source master. I know not all movies are designed to be ultra sharp and shiny, Transformers style etc. However for a great film made by the Coen's and shot by the wonderful Roger Deakins, why don't studios as big as Universal give titles like this some Blu ray justice? Stop short changing the fans...we're getting wise!

This has become a cult classic. It is an interesting mashup of noire detective fiction and a stoner comedy with quite a few borrowings from classic films (Busby Berkley, The Producers), but I didn't find it quite the classic as its reputation would have it. I admit a lot of the stoner humor probably went over my head.

Some have said they think "The Big Lebowski" is a commentary on the Southern California lifestyle and all that. I think it's the Coen brothers doing lunacy, Busby Berkeley, and whatever other craziness they could pack into it. Somehow I got the feeling that Jeff Bridges "Dude" is close to the real guy; he seems so effortless in doing it. Underwear in suitcases, bowling balls, Creedence, lost rugs, Kraftwerk parodies, it's just insanity--and I laughed my head off. Unique, as only the Coen brothers can do it.

Way out west there was this fella... fella I wanna tell ya about. Fella by the name of Jeff Lebowski. At least that was the handle his loving parents gave him, but he never had much use for it himself. Mr. Lebowski, he called himself "The Dude". Now, "Dude" - that's a name no one would self-apply where I come from. But then there was a lot about the Dude that didn't make a whole lot of sense. And a lot about where he lived, likewise. But then again, maybe that's why I found the place so darned interestin'. They call Los Angeles the "City Of Angels." I didn't find it to be that, exactly. But I'll allow there are some nice folks there. 'Course I can't say I've seen London, and I ain't never been to France. And I ain't never seen no queen in her damned undies, so the feller says. But I'll tell you what - after seeing Los Angeles, and this here story I'm about to unfold, well, I guess I seen somethin' every bit as stupefyin' as you'd see in any of them other places. And in English, too. So I can die with a smile on my face, without feelin' like the good Lord gypped me. Now this here story I'm about to unfold took place back in the early '90s - just about the time of our conflict with Sad'm and the I-raqis. I only mention it because sometimes there's a man... I won't say a hero, 'cause, what's a hero? But sometimes, there's a man. And I'm talkin' about the Dude here. Sometimes, there's a man, well, he's the man for his time and place. He fits right in there. And that's the Dude, in Los Angeles. And even if he's a lazy man - and the Dude was most certainly that. Quite possibly the laziest in Los Angeles County, which would place him high in the runnin' for laziest worldwide. But sometimes there's a man, sometimes, there's a man. Aw. I lost my train of thought here. But... aw, hell. I've done introduced him enough

What is there to say about The Big Lebowski, not already out there?

This is a movie has developed a cult following over the years. If you like other movies by the Coen brothers, you will like the Big Lebowski. Other Coen brothers movies are: Blood Simple, Fargo, O Brother Where Art Thou?, No Country for Old Men, True Grit, Raising Arizona, The Hudsucker Proxy, Barton Fink, Burn After Reading. If you like more than one of these movies, you may begin to understand why The Big Lebowski has developed a very large cult following, growing to include the Lebowski Fests held throughout the country

I won't discuss The Big Lebowskis story, plot points, artfulness, or other classic critic bullet points, other than to say that it is loosely based on the 1946 Humphrey Bogart / Lauren Bacall film The Big Sleep. While The Big Sleep is a classic gumshoe story, The Big Lebowski is a comedy. I will also touch on the fact that the acting is great.

As mentioned above if you like other Coen brothers movies, you will like The Big Lebowski on the first time seeing it, but like many Coen brothers stories, you have to watch many times over to get all the little nuances that make their movies great.

This review is about Amazon customer service.

Be careful with these "digital copies" that come with movies.  It's not just a simple download.  You don't just go to the website shown on the redemption slip and download your movie.  In fact, as far as I can see, you never physically possess a digital copy, unless you can rip it as it is streaming or something.  No, the redemption site asks you to choose a vendor and then you get a redemption code for that vendor.  Then you go to that vendor with your code and this gets your movie delivered to your library, not to your computer.  If all goes well, that is.

I chose Amazon, since that's where I bought the boxed set.  My "digital copy" redemption did not go well, however -- I got charged 10 bucks.

I immediately emailed customer service with a complaint.  Bright & early next morning was a reply from an actual person, who said that I'd been charged because the expiration date for the "free digital copy" had expired.  This was in July.  I explained that the expiration date shown on the redemption slip in the boxed set was Dec. 31, 2013, and that if there was some sort of mix-up it was not at my end, but rather a miscommunication between Amazon and Universal (the movie company).

The customer service gal apologized for the inconvenience, immediately credited my account, and simultaneously fired me off a good Amazon redemption code for the movie.  Now, anyone can make a mistake (the botched redemption code), but fixing a mistake so quickly and painlessly for the customer is fine service, if you ask me.  Kinda old-fashioned in today's world, but I'm an old-fashioned kind o' guy.

You are not "out of your element" with Amazon's customer service.

Before I commence with the awarding of Bowling for Movies score on The Big Lebowski, I thought I would share a bird's eye view of the process.  If you've read any of our other movie reviews you'll know we use an elaborate method, utilizing modern technology and a special blend of both quasi aaaaand pseudo-science.  While I can't confirm that this "secret formula" for rendering movies into a comprehensive bowling score resides in a safety deposit box in a major New York bank - I can share with you that I hit the googlemachine (you know, it runs on the innerwebs, it's pretty technical) for reviews, comments, and critic's opinions.  I spend hours contemplating not just my opinion, but Mrs. Lady Movie-Dude's, and Little Miss Movie-Dude's (where appropriate).  It's an intensive process designed to check and recheck every aspect of the review process so that you, faithful Amazon review reader, get the most genuine, the most accurate, the most dependable movie review possible.  We here in the Thomason house know that reviewer/review reader's opinion won't always see eye to eye but the hope is you will see the time and love we lavish on the reviews.

To date, no movie has "bowled" a perfect game.  A down side to the process is we watch movies and then discuss what went wrong - it can interfere with the post movie glow.  Critical analysis is, well, critical and being critical by its very nature, negative.  It forces you to take off the rose-colored glasses and see things for what they really are.  We feel this walking on the darker side of cinema is worth it in the end because of the insight it brings.  What movie could stand up to that sort of microscopic scrutiny?  Well, frankly - none - until now:

The Big Lebowski Bowling for Movies Score... 300 of 300!!!  A perfect score!!!

Long Story Short:
Aging hippie, who lives for bowling, becomes intertwined in a ransom plot gone wrong due to an identity mix up - ..."let me explain something to you, uh, I am not Mr. Lebowski - YOU, are Mr. Lebowski.  I'm The Dude..."  One strange episodic adventure leads to the next and a million dollars goes missing, a gun is pulled on the lanes, and a cowboy known simply as The Stanger gets a decent soft-drink.

Jeff Bridges, John Goodman, Julianne Moore, Steve Buscemi, and John Turturro star in a Cohen brother's masterfully written and directed script which was nearly universally ignored by audiences (hey, 90's cinema was pretty easy to ignore).  This movie has mystery, comedy, irony, it's total fiction yet comes off as 100% authentic.  The characters are richly painted and serve as perfect archetypes living in an equally realistic microcosm inhabited by stoners, Vietnam vets, surfer dudes, pronographers, and hyper-militant feminists.  I originally picked this flick up off the Blockbuster shelf back in the day (which was a Thursday) purely because "Hey, that's the dude from Tron" (we're from California originally, by way of explaining the many dude's in my native tough).  What followed was a far out journey into the far reaches of The Dude's world.  From a reviewer's point of view this movie is perfectly acted, perfectly scripted, perfectly scored.  The Cohen brothers threw out The Real Deal and not just a "ringer" full of dirty underwear.

What I liked:
- Bridges' portrayal as the laziest person in Los Angeles County - he transforms into the most laid-back zen hippie dude and evolved into a very un-dude stress monger as the events unfold... and back to his personal center seamlessly
- If the script is the heart of the movie, the soundtrack is the soul providing the perfect emotional backdrop throughout - from CCR to Kenny Rogers, Bob Dylan to Captain Beefheart; I hate the Eagles but Hotel California in Spanish was simply perfect for Jesus to make his appearance
- The comedy is unforced but flows naturally and organically as these strong personalities collide as the plot's arching mystery bring strangers together under strange circumstances.
- The dream sequences... dude, need to been seen to believed

Who would NOT enjoy this film in my humble opinion:
- People who are allergic to laughing - could cause a serious rash
- People who are overtly uptight - you know who you are (you probably marked it 1 star)
- People who think America peaked in the 1950s
- Rush Limbaugh (what else needs to be said)

Hey, have any question about this movie review??  Drop a comment and I will try to respond as quickly as possible.  Bowling for Movies was in no way shape or form compensated for the review.  Wondering how your favorite movie would score - just ask, if I got it - you'll get it!  And remember, The Movie Dude Abides :]

Just read the opening monologue, and you can understand why this polarizing movieis either a strike or a gutter ball.

"Way out west there was this fella I wanna tell ya about. Goes by the name of Jeff Lebowski. At least that was the handle his loving parents gave him, but he never had much use for it himself. See, this Lebowski, he called himself "The Dude". Now, "Dude" - there's a name no man would self-apply where I come from. But then there was a lot about the Dude that didn't make a whole lot of sense. And a lot about where he lived, likewise. But then again, maybe that's why I found the place so darned interestin'. See, they call Los Angeles the "City Of Angels"; but I didn't find it to be that, exactly. But I'll allow it as there are some nice folks there. 'Course I ain't never been to London, and I ain't never seen France. And I ain't never seen no queen in her damned undies, so the feller says. But I'll tell you what - after seeing Los Angeles, and this here story I'm about to unfold, well, I guess I seen somethin' every bit as stupefyin' as you'd seen in any of them other places. And in English, too. So I can die with a smile on my face, without feelin' like the good Lord gypped me. Now this here story I'm about to unfold took place in the early '90s - just about the time of our conflict with Sad'm and the I-raqis. I only mention it because sometimes there's a man... I won't say a hero, 'cause, what's a hero? Sometimes, there's a man. And I'm talkin' about the Dude here - the Dude from Los Angeles. Sometimes, there's a man, well, he's the man for his time and place. He fits right in there. And that's the Dude. The Dude, from Los Angeles. And even if he's a lazy man - and the Dude was most certainly that. Quite possibly the laziest in all of Los Angeles County, which would place him high in the runnin' for laziest worldwide. Sometimes there's a man, sometimes, there's a man. Well, I lost my train of thought here. But... aw, hell. I've done introduced it enough. "
